data.title: Unable to add Window events in develop3d (Linux)
Split MonoGame.Framework into Seperate Assemblies
data.body:
This is a big job. We need to split the Framework up into seperate assemblies to help cut down on bloat when deploying applications on devices. 

Currently all the code is in one assembly MonoGame.Framework. This has a hard dependency on Lidgren which still has to be deployed even if you dont use networking. 

the plan is to split it out to 

MonoGame.Framework
MonoGame.Framework.Game
MonoGame.Framework.Net
MonoGame.Framework.GamerServices
MonoGame.Framework.Graphics

note there are some internal properties that are being used (to get the game instance for example) this problem needs to be resolved by either using the gameservices stuff or by using "Friend Assemblies" which requires signing.

Note that the existing MonoGame.Framework.<Platform> projects should be left as they are for now, so that if does not affect other teams working on the 3d stuff.

data.title: MGFX Improvements
data.body:
This pull has a bunch more big changes to MGFX.

All the DXEffectObject classes (which originally came from Wine) and all of Mojoshader has been moved from Framework into the 2MGFX tool.  This moves all of this processing and complexity to the offline tool.

The Framework now loads MGFX files directly into the Effect classes vastly simplifying the loading process.

I've decided to not support "preshaders" or "expressions" which has been dropped my Microsoft and will possibly be hard to maintain long term with GLSL.  The stock effect FX files have been modified to use multiple techniques to give the same behavior as "shader indexing".

We also have some other improvements like Effect.Clone() now works and fixed up some Effect apis to match XNA.

The 2MGFX tool now depends on the Framework assembly to get Enums and other objects for serialization of effects.

This commit has been testing on Windows PC and iOS.

The next pull request will have the WinRT bits for Effects.

data.title: GL Errors in iOS OpenGL ES Analyser
data.body:
Hey all,

I ran my game through the Instruments application in iOS using the OpenGL ES Analyser, and it found several calls to GL20 that are being reported as GL_INVALID_OPERATION. 

According to the tool, "The specified operation is invalid for the current OpenGL state.  Due to this error, the function call has no effect."

So, I assume that means that any calls that are invalid can be removed entirely as they are not doing anything to begin with. There are several in SpriteBatch and SpriteBatcher, and I'm curious to see if these could be contributing to bugs, or if it is as simple as unnecessary calls. 

An easy one is:
GL20.Disable(ALL20.Texture2D) in SpriteBatch.cs ~ line 347 is not valid in a GL20 workflow and can be removed.

Another:
SpriteBatcher.cs ~ line 173 - GL20.Uniform1(texID, 0);
I am not very familiar with GL20, so I'm not sure what this was intending to do, but it must not be critical as drawing still occurs.

There are a handful of these, but I am not sure if they are just oops, or if intended functionality is not happening.

data.title: MGFX
data.body:
This pull contains the update to the new MGFX effect file format.  MGFX is MonoGame's own FX file format which has the following goals:
- Support a similar technique, passes, shaders structure as Microsoft FX files.
- Have a textual format for ease of editing.
- Have a compiled and optimized binary format for runtime use.
- Be cross-platform and support OpenGL, GLES, and DirectX shader formats.
- Easy to extend for future platforms and features.

At this time only the binary format of MGFX is implemented for use on OpenGL/GLES.  In the coming weeks I will be adding the textual format and DirectX shader support for WinRT.

There is a new Tools folder in this update which contains the '2MGFX' tool for compiling MGFX files.  It currently goes right from Microsoft FX files to a compiled MGFX file, but will soon support the textual MGFX format as both an input and output format.  The tool currently is Windows only, but we will be fixing it to run on OSX and Linux.

In the MonoGame.Framework\Graphics\Effect\Resources folder you'll find Microsoft's "StockEffects Sample" .FX files along with precompiled .mgfx files and a Windows batch file which converts one into the other.

Note the "ShaderTests" test fails at this moment because they use Microsoft FX files which need to be converted to MGFX.  I will work with kungfubanana to get the right files in there soon.

These changes have been tested on Windows, iOS, and OSX.  It should work fine on Android and Linux, but we have not tested it personally.

data.title: Landscape orientation issue on iPad
data.body:
I just noticed this today. My universal app is set to support LandscapeLeft and LandscapeRight only on iPhone and iPad. When I load it onto the device, i typically start in LandscapeLeft (home button on the left) and everything works as expected. I started my app in LandscapeRight for a change, and the drawing behavior has changed.
1. Stuff drawn using Rendertarget2D are now scaled smaller (taking up the upper left quarter of the space)
2. Places where I do my own GL 2.0 are also scaled the same way.

If I turn the device upside down to LandscapeLeft, my GL 2.0 drawing jumps into correct position and works fine from then on, but all the RenderTarget stuff still looks funny. My best guess is initial settings used by RenderTargets are not reset.

Anyone know what this could be? or where I can start to look? I do not see this behavior on the iPhone.

I CAN get this behavior to happen in the simulator, I have to open it, close the app all the way, rotate the device, then open it again since it defaults to left orientation.

In the simulator, in LandscapeLeft, there is a point during loading where the loading screen blinks upsidedown for a moment before it returns to LandscapeLeft. My best guess is there is an orientation change happening that is forcing the right variables to be initialized or something.

Upon further testing, it looks like if I restrict supported orientations to LandscapeRight ONLY or LandscapeLeft ONLY, the problem presents itself in the simulator right off the bat. Up to now a forced orientation changed event might be what's making it work at all.

data.title: iOS - Texture2D - Change FromFile so you can load from Documents folder
data.body: The FromFile method currently calls UIImage.FromBundle which takes advantage of automatically loading @2x images for high resolution retina devices.  However it can only load files from the Content folder.  The UIImage.FromFile method allows you to load graphics from the document folder as well as the Content folder, however it does not automatically cope with loading @2x images like the FromBundle method does.  Therefore this change will check the path we are trying to load - if it is from the Content folder then we continue to call UIImage.FromBundle, however if it is from anywhere else then we will call UIImage.FromFile.

data.title: Missing OcclusionQuery class from Graphics namespace

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
Someone on twitter who tried to port his app to MonoGame pointed out that we don't have the OcclusionQuery class implemented....

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.graphics.occlusionquery.aspx

Some quick Googling last night shows the OpenGL also has that ability as well and the OpenTK site mentions it here

http://www.opentk.com/doc/chapter/2/opengl/fragment-ops/occlusion-query

Now it seems OcclusionQuery it only valid for the Desktop stack as it is part of OpenGL, but NOT OpenGL ES.

Any suggestions on how we can get it working across all our platforms? Or is it just not worth it due to over heads involved if it is not supported by the mobile hardware?

data.title: Built in Ad revenue support...
data.body:
It would be nice to be able to turn on Ad revenue support on platforms that support them.

The idea being having a flag like ShowiAd = true and then setting a top, bottom left right property to position it.

On iOS it would support iAd, and AdMob and possibly others, and on Android there would be other options.

I think this would add yet another differentiating factor to MonoGame compared to other XNA implementations.

data.title: Game Load Time is extremely long and Textures invisible
data.body:
Hi guys,
i am facing two problems with MonoGame for Android when deploying on a real device.

Development Device/Informations:
- Visual Studio 2010, Monogame 2.5.0.0, Xamarin MonoDroid
- The developement device i am using is a Samsung Galaxy W SGH-T679M (OS 2.3)
- According to the informations i found on the web, the GPU is => Qualcomm Adreno (TM) 205 / OpenGL ES-CM 1.1
- I develop on this device to have as much compatibility as possible with the different devices (old & new)

When porting a Windows Phone XNA game to Android using MonoDroid/MonoGame, the game is working fine, load quickly and everything works well in the emulator.

However, when deploying on a real device i am facing these two problems:

1) Load Time:
- The load time to launch my game vary between 90sec to 120sec. Even when removing any Assets Loading code, the game still take that long to launch.
- I tried the CatapultWars Demo, it take really long to load but the game itself work flawlessly.
- I tried to create an empty OpenGL project with MonoDroid and keep the spinning square demo and it is loading in ~2-3sec. and run really smooth.

---

2) Textures invisible
- Beside the load time problem, my textures are not visible on a real device, even tho everything works fine in the Emulator(OS 2.2). All i can see is the GraphicsDevice.Clear color.
- I am using PNG, non power of 2(work in the emulator anyway). Even when using Power of 2 textures i have no success.

Thanks in advance!
